awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Mean Field Spin Glasses and Related Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
In the 1970s theoretical physicists invented a number of statistical mechanical models, called spin glasses, in order to study the strange behavior of certain alloys, such as CuMn. In mathematics, they are purely probabilistic objects possessing extremely intricate dependence structures and exhibit several crucial features that are commonly shared in many randomized combinatorial systems arising from various scientific fields. As a result, spin glass models are very often cited as examples of complex systems and the corresponding research has been of great use in understanding many real-world problems emerging from, such as, computer science, data science, and many others. This project aims to improve the current mathematical understanding of the mean field spin glass models and to establish theoretical foundations for related applications in data science. An integral part of the project is the development of educational activities including mentoring graduate students and postdoc fellows, developing advanced courses, and supervising undergraduate summer research.
 
The project involves the study of the structure of the functional order parameter and its connection to the fluctuation and the energy landscape of the mean field spin glasses. In addition, the PI plans to investigate the mean field spin glass models by means of the classical statistical mechanics based on the Thouless-Anderson-Palmer approach and analyze its relation to the Parisi theory. The PI will also study spin glass models with more complicated dependence structures including the bipartite model and the Levy spin glass. Furthermore, the PI intends to study some randomized combinatorial optimization problems arising from data science in the approach of spin glass theory such as the detection problems and positive semi-definite programming. Based on these research projects, the educational component involves organizing probability summer programs and mentoring graduate, undergraduate students as well as postdoc fellows.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This proposal is concerned with the asymptotic behavior in a certain class of probabilistic models, called spin glasses. They are statistical physics models invented by the theoretical physicists in the late '70 in order to explain some unusual magnetic behavior of certain metallic alloys, such as CuMn and AuFe. Mathematically, they are disordered spin systems or stochastic processes indexed by spin configurations and are known to exhibit several profound features that are commonly shared in many real-world applications involving randomized optimization problems in high-dimension. Over the past decades, the study of spin glasses has been one of the prominent components in statistical physics and has produced many fascinating and deep mathematics. In particular, thanks to the breakthrough works of G. Parisi (Nobel Laureate in Physics 2021), M. Talagrand (Abel Prize 2024), and many others, we have a much better understanding for the class of mean-field spin glass models. However, there are still many fundamental and challenging problems that remain open. This proposal is focused to answer some major questions including understanding the structure of the functional order parameter and its connection to the fluctuation and the energy landscape of the mixed p-spin model. Another major direction is to understand the mean-field spin glasses by means of the classical statistical mechanics based on the Thouless-Anderson-Palmer (TAP) approach and to investigate its relation to the Parisi theory. Furthermore, extending the existing methodologies to analyze spin glass models with more intricate dependence structures, such as, the bipartite model and the Levy spin glass is one of the critical components in this proposal.

Intellectual Merit: This proposal has sought to answer the questions mentioned above and has achieved some significant progress. One of the major developments is the full description of the TAP representation for the limiting free energy in the famous Sherrington-Kirkpatrick model at any temperature. The results confirmed not only some important predictions of physicists, but also proposed a new idea of controlling the free energy landscape by introducing a novel effective field. Another line of achievements attained some new results on the statistical inference problems of spiked Gaussian tensor models and on the algorithmic perspectives in the computation of some related spin glass quantities. Lastly, a comprehensive study on the free energy of the Levy model associated to any power law distribution of an arbitrary order between zero and two was successfully performed during the funding period

Broader Impacts: The outcome of this proposal is generally expected to advance our current understanding of the mean-field spin glasses and related applications. In particular, the TAP approach carried out in this proposal can be potentially considered as a general recipe for motivating innovative iterative methods in high-dimensional statistics and machine learnings. The study in light of the statistical and algorithmic aspects of the spin glass models carried out in this project is also expected to be of highly applicable to a broad class of random optimization problems in statistics and computer science. Finally, an integral component of this proposal involved educational goals including student and postdoctoral mentorships and organizing two summer schools at the undergraduate and junior graduate level on some topics in random optimizations related to the problems in this proposal.
